Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A novel framework for mining graph patterns in large biological and social networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Frequent subgraph mining is a core task in data mining which can be applied to various real-life problems related to graphs and networks. Presently, the research value of this task has been heightened by the increased availability of massive network data in the domains of life and social sciences. However, existing algorithms for subgraph mining suffer from various limitations; noteworthy among these are lack of scalability, lack of user interaction and the absence of a mechanism to mine dynamic graphs. This research aims to overcome the above limitations by accomplishing the following three related tasks: (1) use of Monte Carlo sampling mechanisms for designing scalable graph mining algorithms; (2) develop real-time interactive graph mining systems using subgraph sampling approaches; and (3) discover models for graph evolution that are based on sampling and driven by the principles of game theory and economics.

This research builds a novel paradigm for subgraph mining that is based on Monte Carlo sampling. This allows the development of algorithms that are scalable, by avoiding the need to enumerate all subgraph patterns. The resulting algorithms will be applied to subgraph mining problems in systems biology, e.g., predicting disease pathways by mining graphs from genomics and proteomics co-expression networks. A second outcome of this research is an interactive pattern mining framework using subgraph sampling where user feedback guides updates of the sampling distribution such that subsequent sampling prioritizes patterns that are considered "interesting" to the user. A third outcome is a subgraph sampling method that uses a game theoretic mechanism to design a subgraph evolution model for prediction tasks (such as link prediction) in dynamic networks.

Broader Impacts: Availability of tools for mining large graphs enables the opportunity to build network biomarkers, which are novel signatures for disease diagnosis and risk factor analysis. A sampling based interactive pattern system is instrumental to mine "interesting" associations between diseases and medicines from numerous hidden datasets that are currently unexplored in many hospitals and health clinics. Scalable graph mining algorithms are also likely to find use in search, e-commerce and social networks based industry. The educational goal of this research is to leverage the PI's industrial experience to develop a "Large-scale data analysis" course on methods needed to build data mining systems that work on industry-scale data.

Additional information about the project, including the findings, methods, open source implementations of algorithms, publications and data can be accessed through the project website at http://www.cs.iupui.edu/~alhasan/graph_mining.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mining graph patterns is an important problem in many disciplines including bioinformatics, social network analysis, and cyber-security. For instance, frequently occurring graphical patterns, aka network motif, which exist in the biological networks play key roles in important cellular activities. In the social networks, such graphical patterns explain the emergence and demise of social groups, interaction among various social groups, and the role of a given node within its social groups. Understanding the above phenomena is fundamental for national security and counter-terrorism activities. Graph evolution patterns also explain the way how computer viruses and malwares propagate over physical computer networks. A better understanding of malware propagation pattern can help us developing defense mechanisms for protecting infrastructure, and complex connected system. However, most of the real-life networks are dense, and mining frequently occurring sub-networks in these networks is a complex and time-consuming task. Besides, due to combinatorial nature of graph patterns, there are too many patterns from which finding useful patterns is a difficult task. Research using this grant has overcome the above two crucial challenges.


This NSF grant has produced methodologies for efficient discovery of frequent subgraph patterns, and network motifs. First, this grant has produced distributed graph mining methods, which are scalable. Second,  It has introduced a new research direction in graph mining that is based on Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling. The key idea of this direction is that by uniform sampling of small-sized subgraphs from a host graph (or a collection of host graphs in a graph database) we can discover graph patterns that are frequent in the host graph (or over the graphs in the graph database). This overcomes the lack of scalability issue that all the existing graph mining algorithms face.  PI has also shown that sampling can be an effective alternative to exhaustive counting for building frequency histogram of small subgraphs in a large network, which can then be used for building a compact signature to characterize networks from different domains. By observing the deviation from the usual signature  for networks in a give domain, one can build machine learning methods for detecting anomaly.  PI has used such methodologies to detect malware from mobile applications. In another work, he has used the proposed sampling based frequent subgraph mining methodologies for building functional pathways from protein interface graphs.

Another contribution of this grant is to develop methodologies for interactive mining of frequent patterns. This approach helps building patterns that are customized to the need of a user. PI has shown that such methods can be used for two purposes: first to summarize frequent patterns and returns a small list of patterns that are customized to a analysis task, such as classification or clustering; second, for building active learning methodologies. As a case study, PI have shown that frequent patterns selected by interactive user feedback can be used for effective real estate search. Another crucial discovery from this research is to develop methods for mining patterns from hidden databases, a direction that can open further research for mining patterns from private data sources, such as patient data, crime data, etc.

Two book chapters, seven journal articles, and sixteen conference articles are produced over the lifetime of this grant. Five open-source software, namely GUISE, GRAFT, FS^3, PRIIME, and TopCom have been released in github repository.  GUISE can be used for uniform sampling of subgraph patterns and for building graphlet frequency distribution based graph signature.  GRAFT can be used for counting graphlets exactly. FS^3 can be used for mining frequent subgraphs using sampling based method. PRIIME can be used for mining patterns (set, sequence, or graphs) by interactive input from the user. Finally, TopCom can be used for indexing shortest paths in large graphs. Four PhD students were supported with this grant in different capacities. Two of the PhD students have graduated and are now working as research scientists in the USA. PI has given tutorials on Network Sampling in premier data mining conferences (KDD, ICDM, SDM) for making sampling based graph mining methods popular to the data mining and machine learning community. Several papers published from this grant are highly cited, reaching more than 40 citations in about four years. Research data, papers, and results from this grant are available to public and research community from this website: http://dmgroup.cs.iupui.edu.
